newsitem.title: CAMEROON: Cameroon to hold parliamentary election in May.
newsitem.headline: Cameroon to hold parliamentary election in May.

text.p: Cameroon will hold its postponed parliamentary election in May, according to a government statement.
The statement, issued after a cabinet meeting on Saturday, did not give any date. A source close to President Paul Biya's office said polling would be in the first half of May.
The election will be the second parliamentary poll since Cameroon's sometimes turbulent transition to multi-party democracy began in 1990.
Part of the opposition boycotted the last legislative election in 1992. Biya supporters secured a majority then after allying with a minor party.
The government postponed this year's election from March after opposition party complaints that their activists had not had enough time to register.
The government postponement order said the aim was to prevent tension and street clashes that had characterised previous elections.
A second reason for the postponement was to allow time to set up a constitutional council to proclaim results and vet any complaints from candidates.
The opposition has demanded an independent national electoral commission.
Biya, who took over from independence president Ahmadou Ahidjo in 1982, faces a presidential election in October.
